summary: Paul Wallach served as the Chief Counsel of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence in 1975 and 1976. He was involved in the Senate's investigation into intelligence activities, including those related to the CIA and the JFK assassination. Wallach's role included interviewing individuals, requesting access to documents, and participating in hearings. He specifically engaged with the CIA regarding the release of files related to Lee Harvey Oswald and the Kennedy assassination, balancing transparency with the protection of sensitive sources and methods. He also participated in interviews related to Task Force W and Operation Mongoose.
significance: As Chief Counsel of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, Paul Wallach played a key role in investigating the CIA's involvement in the JFK assassination and related intelligence activities. His work involved accessing sensitive information and interviewing key individuals, contributing to the understanding of the events surrounding the assassination.
